name: matric

[ C or U ] a public exam in a range of subjects that is taken by some children in their final year of high school in South Africa, or the qualification from this: The names of the students who have passed matric are published in newspapers across South Africa. He will study at Central Johannesburg College, a technical school that does not require a matric pass.
[ C or U ] a public exam in a range of subjects that was taken in the past in English and Welsh schools by some children aged 15 or 16, or the qualification from this: The matric was first introduced in England and Wales in 1873. Academic work came relatively easily to him and he passed his matrics without undue effort.
[ U ] UK short for
matriculation : the process of formally becoming a student at a university or college: Only a few freshers attended the official matric ceremony.
